Todas las tardes y noches ella también se dedica a la venta de comidas rápidas y lo que más vende son los chuzos (carne en palito) y alitas de pollo asadas con plátano asado, nos cuenta que lleva más de dos años dedicada a estas actividades y dice que le va bastante bien.

Este crédito lo va a invertir en sus dos negocios, va a comprar productos para preparar sus bocadillos como: alitas de pollo, plátano, carne de res, salchichas y sodas,  también va a comprar ropa de todo tipo para la venta.

Sus metas son seguir adelante en sus negocios y que sus hijos tengan lo mejor.
texts.en:
Every two weeks, the 1 de Diciembre Community Bank meets in the coastal town of San Clemente. This place is known for its beautiful beaches, which are visited by many national and international tourists, has many different beautiful places, and a rich variety of traditional regional food.

Maritza lives here, is twenty-five years old, and, with her common-law husband, has two children, a four year old and a two year old. Her husband is a fisherman. She has received nine loans from the community bank, and is happy with the benefits the institution offers.

In addition to being a very good housewife, our friend is also a businesswoman. Three or four times a week she travels around her town offering the wide variety of clothing that she sells. She also sells fast food every afternoon and evening. Her biggest sellers are chuzo (skewered meat) and roasted chicken wings with roasted platano. She tells us she has spent more than two years working this way, and says that she is doing pretty well.

She plans to invest the loan in her two businesses. She is going to purchase ingredients to prepare sandwiches: chicken wings, platano, beef, sausage, and soda pop. She also is going to purchase a wide variety of clothing to sell.

Her goals are to get ahead with her businesses and to provide the best for her children.

loans.use: To purchase chicken wings, platanos, beef, sausage, soda pop, and clothing.

loans.name: Terimbere Muhinzi 52 / Rsz Group

texts.fr:
Félicien fait partie du groupe Terimbere Muhinzi 52 / RSZ et sur la photo est celui qui a l’argent. Le nom du groupe signifie « may you develop yourself, farmer ! ». Il est né au Rwanda et il a 49 ans. Il est marié avec 8 enfants de 4 à 21 ans, dont 8 scolarisés. Son niveau d’éducation est 2 ans de primaire. 

Félicien est cultivateur de riz. C’est son premier cycle de prêt avec ACB. Il va utiliser son crédit afin d’acheter des engrais chimiques pour son agriculture de riz. 

Dans les prochaines années, Félicien voudrait récolter une grande quantité de riz. Avec les profits, il prévoit d’éduquer et soigner ses enfants.
texts.en: Félicien (the man in the picture holding the money) is part of the Terimbere Muhinzi 52 / RSZ group. The name of the group means "May you develop yourself, farmer!". Félicien was born in Rwanda and is 49 years old. He is married with 8 children aged between 4 and 21, all of whom go to school. He completed 2 years of primary school, and is a rice farmer. This is his first loan cycle with ACB and he will use the money to buy chemical fertilizer for his rice farm. In the next few years, he hopes to be harvesting large amounts of rice and he plans to use the profits from his business to take care of his children and pay for their education.

loans.use: to buy chemical fertilizer for his rice farm.

loans.name: Felix Alvaro

texts.es:
En el municipio de Telica departamento de León el señor Félix Álvaro es casado y con 2 hijos en edad escolar, a los que tiene el deber de mantener sus estudios. Él se dedica a atender su propia pulpería desde hace 18 años en el municipio.

Desde que inició el negocio, el señor Félix se ha caracterizado por ser una persona muy esforzado ya que inició vendiendo con una pequeña cantidad de productos a raíz que fue teniendo experiencia y darse a reconocer  se fue incrementado la demanda de clientes y productos de la pulpería donde ha logrado mantener su núcleo familiar. 

Una de las necesidades que atraviesa es la urgencia de comprar productos de la pulpería como granos básicos, arroz, frijoles, azúcar al igual que productos varios como jabones, pasta dental, papel higiénico entre otros, es por este motivo que acude a Ceprodel para ser beneficiado con un crédito y continuar comercializando, satisfacer la demanda y tener los ingresos para mantener a su familia.
texts.en:
Sr. Félix Álvaro is married, has two children who are of school age, and lives in the town of Telica in the Department of León.  In order to provide for his children’s education, he has managed a store for 18 years in the town of Telica in the region of Tololar León.  

Since starting his business, Félix has been known for being a very determined individual.  He started selling products in small quantities in order to gain experience and recognition.  The demand from his customers for his products increased, so he was able to support his family.  

One of his urgent needs at the moment is to buy products for his store such as basic grains, rice, beans, sugar, as well as other items such as soap, toothpaste, toilet paper, etc.  For this reason, Félix has approached CEPRODEL so that he could benefit from a loan in order to continue selling, satisfying customer demand, and generating income to support his family.

loans.use: to buy merchandise for his store.

loans.name: Neftali

texts.es:
Neftali tiene 47 años, es casado y tiene un hijo. Neftali comenzo a dedicarse a la agricultura desde los 12 años. Dicho oficio lo aprendio de su padre, quien con el afan de enseñarle a su hijo a trabajar no le permitio a Neftali ir a la escuela. Por ende Neftali tiene 35 años de experiencia como agricultor, y le gusta lo que él hace.

Neftali ha pedido un préstamo a Fundacion Campo para 10,500 metros cuadrados de tierra, donde el cultiva maiz y frijol. Debido a que la zona donde vive y cultiva Neftali es muy rural, el transporte es muy escaso y a Neftali se le dificulta llevar todos los insumos a su cultivo. Con la ayuda del préstamo Neftali ha podido comprar todo los insumos que necesita de una sola ves, adquiriendolos a mejor precio y ahorrandose el costo de tener que hacer varios viajes.

En un futuro Neftali quisiera poder sembrar una mayor cantidad, y poder obtener mayores cosechas para la venta.
texts.en:
Neftali is 47 years old, married, and he has a son. Neftali started out in agriculture when he was 12 years old. He learned the business from his father, who, for the sake of teaching his son to work, did not let Neftali go to school. Therefore Neftali has 35 years' experience as an agriculturist, and he loves what he does.

Neftali has requested a loan from Fundacion Campo (Kiva Field Partner) to invest in the 10500 square meters of land where he cultivates corn and beans. The region where Neftali lives is very rural so transportation is very limited. Neftali's challenge is transporting all of the materials to his land. With the help of this loan Neftali has been able to purchase all of the materials he needs all at once, obtaining a better price and saving on the cost of making several trips.

In the future Neftali would like to plant in larger quantities to increase his harvests for sale.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for the 10,500 square meters of farmland where he cultivates corn and beans.

loans.name: Dawui

texts.fr:
Dawui est une femme de 33 ans. Elle est mariée å commerçant. Elle a 03 enfants, qui vont  à l’école. Le plus grand a 16ans et le plus petit a 07ans.  
Dawui travaille comme revendeuse de bois de chauffe et de charbon de bois depuis 2008. Elle vend à toute personne à la maison. Elle travaille seule. 
Dawui a requis son troisième cycle de prêt à WAGES afin d’acheter des bois et des sacs de charbon. Elle veut utiliser les profits supplémentaires pour payer la scolarité de ses enfants.
Dans les prochaines années, Dawui voudrait avoir d’autres points de vente. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, Elle prévoit d’assurer la réussite de ses enfants sur le plan professionnel.
texts.en: Dawui is a 33 year old woman.  She is married to a businessman.  She has 3 children who attend school. The oldest is 16 years old and the youngest is 7 years old.  Dawui has worked as a retailer of firewood and wood charcoal since 2008.  She sells to everyone from her home.  She works alone.  Dawui is requesting her third round of loans from WAGES in order to purchase wood and bags of charcoal.  She will used the additional profits to pay for her children's education.  In the coming years, Dawui would like to have another point of sale.  She says that with the profits, she plans to ensure the professional success of her children.

loans.use: to buy bags of wood charcoal

loans.name: Petronillar

texts.en:
Petronillar is a 25-year-old woman. She has one child. She describes herself as honest, trustworthy, and God fearing. Petronillar operates a beauty salon business, where she provides hair and beauty services to the local people. She has been involved in this business for seven years. Her business is located in a shopping center. 

Petronillar describes her biggest business challenge to be her clients' low purchasing power. She will use the Kes 20,000 loan to buy salon equipment. Her business goal is to grow her business and open other outlets within five years.

loans.use: to buy salon equipment.

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline is 52 years old. She is married and has four children.

She earns a living by raising pigs in the Philippines. Evangeline is borrowing PHP 15000 through NWTF to buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

Evangeline has been raising pigs for 12 years and also earns additional income from food vending.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy feed and vitamins for her pigs.

loans.name: Leonora

texts.en:
Leonora is 57 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married. 

Leonora has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has had this business for 10 years. She requested a loan for PHP 9,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

Leonora has been a member of HSPFI since 2008. In the future, Leonora hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages.

loans.name: Zoriada

texts.en:
Zoriada, 42, is a married woman with six children. She resides in Sumalig in the municipality of Tambulig, a part of Zamboanga del Sur province in the Philippines.

Zoriada has harvested and sold farm-raised fish to her local community for the past six years. Each month she earns 12,000 PHP doing this type of work.

Zoriada has been a member of GDMPC for a year. She has requested a loan of 25,000 PHP to purchase additional fish to raise. Zoriada’s goal is to save her money for future emergencies.

loans.use: to purchase additional fish to raise.

loans.name: Dung

texts.en: Dung is 54-years-old with 4 children who are grown. Being a farmer, he focuses on raising chickens for meat. He's been in this work for 10 years and earns 5,000,000 Vietnam dong per month from this. Joining in our credit program in 2007, he used the loans to buy food and also repair the house. Currently,  he wants to have a loan of 9,632,000 Vietnam dong to buy food for chickens.

loans.use: to buy food for  chickens.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy second-hand shoes to resell

loans.name: Sarlyn

texts.en:
This is Sarlyn, 37, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Ricardo, a salesman, and is the mother of six children. By the grace of God, she has managed to support her older children's schooling up to high school level. At this time, she is working hard to send her children to school. 

Sarlyn operates an auto supply and car accessories business. What she basically does is buy car parts and accessories from wholesalers and sell them per item for a profit. Customers are attracted to buy due to the low selling prices and the many options they are offered. Her regular customers are car owners in the local community.  She earns a minimum of PHP 1,000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 27,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of car parts and accessories to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Sarlyn dreams of being able to give her all her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week, and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for additional stocks of car parts and accessories for her business.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is married with four children and two of whom go to school.  She also takes care of additional family members . She sales fruits and vegetables and has been in this business for 5 years. She has applied for a loan of 600,000 Uganda shillings from MCDT-SACCO to buy a box of tomatoes,onions,egg plants,cabbages,galic . She works for seven days a week.  She is aspiring of becoming a wholesaler and also to buy iron sheets to roof her rental houses.  She decided to join MCDT-SACCO because she wanted additional capital for her business. She resides in the family house and the family has access to electricity and   piped water. Her monthly expenses includes school fees and feeding the family

loans.use: To buy a box of tomatoes,onions,egg plants,cabbages,galic

loans.name: Kiril

texts.en:
Kiril R. is 58 years old man from the very small village Lessicheri, close to Pavlikeni town. He used to work as a director of the only one producing manufacture of carpets in the region, but after the changes in Bulgaria and the followed privatization from two years he is unemployed.

He has a strong experience of the carpet sector, that’s why he took the decision to continue doing this job, but in the private sector. With his own resources he managed to buy a machine for carpet and woolen yam production on very low price, but now to start the real business he needs additional funding of 2 000 USD to buy wool and to start to card it and after that to sell it.

The production of carded wool and carded woolen carpets is very typical for the region of Bulgaria. Starting working as a wool merchant and a producer of woolen carpets he will help his family to survive in this place, they are working in. He has a wife, who is unemployed, а sоn and a granddaughter.

loans.use: To buy wool and to start to  card it

loans.name: Emelia

texts.en: Emelia has a shop which sells tomato paste, cooking oils and other cooking ingredients. She gets stock directly from the manufacturers and later sells retail to her customers. She wants to purchase more stock, therefore she is seeking a loan of $1000.00 from Kiva to enable her expand.

loans.use: To expand her stock

loans.name: Farzhana

texts.en: Farzhana lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is a tailor. She is married and lives with members of her family and she wants to help her husband support her family. She wants to take a group loan to expand her business and buy new machines because she wants to send her children to good schools to be educated. She hopes that if she works hard to be a good business dealer in the future she will make a good monthly income for her family.

loans.use: To buy new machines

loans.name: Alejandrina

texts.en:
Twelve years ago, Alejandrina bought a doll in Cuzco and was dissatisfied with its quality, an event that inspired her to begin making her own dolls.  Since then, she has greatly expanded her doll-making business, selling her items in cities all over Peru.  With the help of her 4 children, Alejandrina works from 6 AM to 10 PM each day, producing at least 200 dolls which she then sells to retailers.  Recently, Alejandrina has expanded her business to include woven items including backpacks, gloves, hats, and sweaters, an enterprise that also allows her to provide employment to many of the women in her loan group.

With a $425 loan, can continue to improve the quality of her products by improving the quality of materials she uses. Alejandrina would someday like to open her own store in Lima where she would exclusively sell products she has made by hand.  She would also like to begin exporting her products to other countries, a goal which requires that she constantly focus on improving the quality of her goods.  If able to open her own store, Alejandrina will be able to enjoy the freedom and profits that accompany self-employment.

loans.use: Improve quality of dolls and woven items.

loans.name: Casiano

texts.es:
Caciano lives on Carmen Álvarez Street, in the February 16 district of the city of El Alto. He dedicates himself to the manufacture of footwear, which he and his wife sell in different street fairs and markets around the city. He has two children, 10 and 4 years old. The demand for his products is rising. He would use the loan to buy supplies (leather, glue, and so on) and in this way increase his income. This is his first loan with IMPRO. The evaluation IMPRO conducted qualifies him to receive this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Antonio and Sarah Padial, Kiva Volunteers

Caciano, vive en la calle Carmen Álvarez, de la zona 16 de Febrero, de La ciudad de El Alto. Se dedica a la elaboración de calzados, los cuales los comercializa junto a su esposa en las diferentes ferias de la ciudad. Su familia actualmente consta de dos hijos menores de 10 y 4 años. El crédito le invertirá en la compra de mercadería (cuero, pegamento, etc) para su negocio y así mejorar sus ingresos económicos, pues la demanda por sus calzados se ha incrementado. Es el primer crédito con Impro. La evaluación realizada lo califica para otorgarle el crédito.

loans.use: Compra de materia prima

loans.name: Ejime

texts.en: Mrs. Ejime B. lives in Asaba, Delta State. She is 48 years old and is married with two children. She sells fish feed. She spent six months learning about this business, and she opened her business in 2006. She is requesting a loan of $800 to buy more fish feed to sell. She has been with LAPO for eight years now.

loans.use: To buy fish feed to sell

loans.name: Alaba

texts.en: Alaba F. is 35 years old and a mother of 2. She hails from Mushin in Lagos State, Nigeria. She is into the production and supply of sugar and salt. She is a LAPO member. Alaba needs the loan to buy materials for production of salt and sugar for sale.

loans.use: To buy more material for production of salt and sugar

loans.name: Marina's Group

texts.es:
Mayra, Marina and Edith have belonged to the Community Bank of Your Angel Lucy for 3, 6 and 3 years respectively. They say that in the bank they have learned to be responsible, united and punctual.

Mayra is a 23 year old single mother with one child. She sells clothing by order. Her sales are maD. on credit which she recoups daily. Mayra has been doing this work for 2 years.

Marina is 50 years old and has four children. She has been baking bread for 3 years and sells them in the “Market: April 12th.” To begin with she sold gelatins and after receiving a loan from the Community Bank began her bakery.

Edith is 21 years old and has one child. Edith, along with her husband, have ran a bar for the last 5 years. The bar is located in the center of the city.

Mayra, Marina and Edith need a loan of S/. 1,400 ($450.00), S/. 1,000 ($350.00) and S/. 1,000 ($350.00) respectively. These funds will be invested in pants, shirts, sweaters, blouses, skirts, soda-pop, beer, and flour. The dreams of Mayra, Marina and Edith are to construct there own homes, have their own oven, have good health, and improve their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Casey Unrein, Kiva volunteer.

Mayra, Marina y Edith pertenecen al Banco Comunal Tu Ángel Lucy desD. hace 3, 6 y 3 años respectivamente. Ellas dicen que en su Banco Comunal aprendieron a ser responsables, solidarias y puntuales. Mayra es madre soltera, tiene 23 años y 1 hijo. Ella venD. ropa a pedido, sus ventas los realiza al crédito y cobra diariamente, actividad que realiza desD. hace 2 años. Por otro lado Marina tiene 50 años y 4 hijos y elabora panes desD. hace 3 años y los venD. en el mercado 12 D. abril. En un inicio vendía gelatina y con los préstamos que sacó D. su Banco Comunal comenzó su negocio actual. Mientras que Edith tiene 21 años y 1 hijo. Edith junto a su esposo tienen un bar desD. hace 5 años y su bar está ubicado en el centro D. la ciudad. Mayra, Marina y Edith necesitan préstamos D. 1400 soles, 1000 soles, 1000 soles respectivamente, que serán invertidos en la compra D. pantalones, polos, chompas, blusas, faldas, gaseosas, cervezas, harina. Los sueños D. Mayra, Marina y Edith son construir su casa, tener su horno propio, tener buena salud y mejorar sus negocios.

loans.use: Purchase of goods for their respective businesses (pants, shirts, sweaters, blouses, skirts, soda-pop, beer, and flour).

loans.name: Isabel Bernardo

texts.pt:
Isabel Bernardo M. lives with her partner and three children in Maputo, Mozambique. She is in the business of buying coconuts in the province of Inhambane and taking them to South Africa to sell. She joined the credit program as part of the Magoanine group and now, on her second loan cycle, is applying for an individual loan of $275 to improve her coconut business.

Translated from Portuguese by Aline Pereira, Kiva Volunteer.

Isabel Bernardo M., portadora do BI nº 110342133R vive maritalmente mãe de 3 filhos é residente 3 de fevereiro é negociante de cocos compra os cocos em inhambane e vende na Africa do sul entrou no programa como elemento do grupo Magoanine tomava o valor de 1800 agora esta a tomar sozinha esta no 2º ciclo vai tomar o valor de 6000 mt a pagar em 6 meses para aumentar o seu negocio.

loans.use: To invest in coconut business

loans.name: Nighat's Group

texts.en:
My name is Nighat B.. I am a widow with five children; three boys and two girls. Both of my daughters are married and two of the boys are working. One son attends school. I sell various hair oils from my house. I want to expand my oils business and am requesting a loan for this purpose.

My group members have been together for the past three years. They are requesting the loan to use as follows: Jameela B. sells cloth and would like to increase her inventory. Bushra B. is borrowing money for her husband who supplies construction materials. Mukhtar B. will buy toys. Rani B. will buy a sewing machine with her share of loan.

loans.use: Buy hair oils in bulk

loans.name: Salustio

texts.es:
Salustio F. is and active and enterprising 64 year old. He lives with his wife, Leonarda Gimenez, and two grown daughters. Both his daughters work at the national hospital of Itagúa, one of the largest in the country. Salustio is very proud of his daughters because, despite coming from such a humble family, they have not left their studies or stopped working in order to get ahead and help their parents.

Salustio devotes himself to the sale of charcoal and, as a result of his earnings from this activity as well as some loans, he was able to open a store in his home that his wife can manage and obtain additional income for the family. He reports to us that when he lost his job, the Fundación Paraguaya was the only entity that granted him credit to start his small business. They provided help despite his inability to supply references or show evidence of a fixed source of income.

His general store is called “San Cateyano” (“Saint Cateyano”) who is their patron saint of abundance and work. They began by selling merchandise such as soda, beer, wine and whiskey. Later, they added to this baked goods, herbs, sugar, sweets, rice and noodles, among other items.

Salustio has not been able to carry out his charcoal selling activities over the last month because he is suffering from an infirmity that doesn’t allow him to focus 100% on this effort. For this reason he wants to reinforce his sales at the general store as these are, for the moment, the primary means of income for the family other than the daughters’ small salaries which cannot support them.

The loan he is seeking would be used to better supply the store, since the neighbors in the area request certain types of products such as canned goods, cleaning supplies, meat, and fruits and vegetables.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn, Kiva Volunteer.

El Sr. Salustio F. tiene 64 años, es una persona muy activa y emprendedora, vive con su esposa Leonarda Giménez, y su dos hijas las cuales ya son mayores de edad, ambas trabajan en el Hospital Nacional de Itagúa, uno de los más grandes hospitales del País. Salustio se siente orgulloso de sus hijas, pues a pesar de que la familia es muy humilde ellas no han dejado de estudiar y trabajar para salir adelante y ayudar a sus padres.

Salustio se dedica a la venta de carbón y de las ganancias que le ha generado esta actividad más algunos créditos también pudo montar una despensa en su hogar para que su esposa lo pueda administrar y obtener mayores ingresos a la familia. Cuenta que cuando quedo sin trabajo, la Fundación Paraguaya fue la única entidad que le otorgo los créditos para empezar su microempresa, ya que el no contaba con referencias ni ingresos fijos.

Su despensa lleva por nombre “San Cayetano” que es el santo patrono de la abundancia y el trabajo. Empezaron vendiendo mercaderías como gaseosas, cervezas, vinos, whiskys, luego fue agregando la venta de panificado, yerba, azúcar, golosinas, arroz, fideos entre otros.

Salustiano no ha podido cumplir con sus ventas de carbón en el último mes pues padece de una enfermedad que no le permite el 100% en la atención de sus ventas y repartos de carbón. Por ello desean reforzar sus ventas de la despensa ya que es por el momento la principal fuente de ingresos de la familia además del salario de sus hijas pero que no alcanza para cubrir todos los gastos de la casa y medicamentos del padre.

El crédito que solicita lo utilizará para surtir mejor sus mercaderías en la despensa, ya que los vecinos de la zona ya le solicitaron ciertas mercaderías que ellos desean como productos enlatados, artículos de limpieza para el hogar, carne, frutas y verduras.

loans.use: Purchase drinks such as soda, beer, wine, whiskey, as well as candy, charcoal, cookies, sugar and herbs.

loans.name: Sangeeta

texts.en: Sangeeta Bibi, wife of Mr. S., has been married for five years and has one daughter and one son. Her husband runs a rented grocery shop. He has been in this profession for the last four years.. Sangeeta understands the importance of savings, therefore she regularly deposits her  savings in a local bank.  Sangeeta’s husband needs to diversify the products range at his store so that he can serve a larger number of clients and therefore needs a loan.

loans.use: To diversify the product range of a grocery store

loans.name: Ermelinda

texts.es:
Ermelinda is 57 years old, is married, and has two children, both of which are indepedent professionals. Ermelinda comments that she is very proud of her children.

She has had a store and eatery for about 7 years, which she began by selling quickly prepared food and providing lunch at the requests of workers that began working at a large paper factory. When the factory got running and incorporated more jobs, Ermelinda started her store, hoping to offer a great variety of products to her clientele. Ermelinda mentions that she has put a lot of love into this endeavor, and thanks to her good treatment of customers, she maintains steady clientele.

Ermelinda is asking for this loan to buy merchandise such as beef, chicken, flour, oil, rice, sugar, sodas, drinks, bread, and other provisions for the store.

Translated by Maggie Messerschmidt, Kiva volunteer.

La Sra. Ermelinda tiene 57 años de edad, esta casada, tiene 2 hijos, ambos mayores independientes y profesionales, comenta que esta orgullosa de los mimos.

Ermelinda tiene un despensa y comedor hace aproximadamente 7 años, se inició con la venta de comidas rápidas y a proveer almuerzos a pedidos de unos obreros que iniciaban la obra de una gran fabrica de papel. Cuando la fábrica empezó a funcionar y se incorporaron los nuevos funcionarios, Ermelinda habilitó un salón comercial en donde habilitó un comedor y una despensa con el fin de brindar mayor variedad de productos a su clientela. Menciona la señora que en todo esto ella deposita mucho amor a su trabajo y gracias a su buen trato mantiene una buena clientela.

Solicita el crédito para compras de mercaderías como: carne, pollo, harina, aceite, arroz, azúcar, golosinas, bebidas en general, panificados y otros.

loans.use: Buy merchandise such as: beef, chicken, flour, oil, rice, sugar, sodas, drinks, bread, and others.

loans.name: Em

texts.en:
Mr. P. Em and his wife, Mrs. Saroeun Mil, who live about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh, were married during the Pol Pot regime and have six children, four sons and two daughters. Three of their children are married and live outside the family home. Of the remaining three, one is a security guard, another a garment factory worker, and the last one a student in the local school.

Mr. P. has been a gardener for four years, while his wife is a garment factory worker. The family lives in a Khmer wooden house, but its staircase is old and broken. Therefore he is requesting a loan of $600 to build a new staircase.

loans.use: To build a staircase for his house.

loans.name: Maria Luisa

texts.es:
Maria Luisa is requesting her third loan; this time the loan will be invested in adding a room to her home. Her monthly income as a elementary school teacher is about 220 US dollars; she has been a teacher for 14 years.

Maria Luisa is a single mother of a 12-year-old boy, who is in the sixth grade. Despite being a single mother, Maria Luisa has provided her son all that he needs. This school teacher has proven to be responsible, honest, hard-working, as well as a good mother and teacher.

Maria Luisa is also enrolled in URACCAN University to improve her education. Her dream is to have a good home, a stable job, good health, and to see her son continue his studies and progress.

Translated from Spanish by Maria B., Kiva volunteer

Doña María Luisa está solicitando su tercer refinanciamiento para invertirlo en mejora de su vivienda ( Construcción de una habitación), su ingreso mensual que devenga como docente de Educación primaria es de C$ 4297.00 equivalente a U$ 220.00, lleva 14 años dedicándose a esta profesión, esta clienta tiene 1 hijo de 12 años el cual estudia su sexto grado de Educación Primaria. A pesar que es una madre soltera, a su hijo no le ha faltado nada, esta docente se ha destacado por ser responsable , honesta, trabajadora, buena maestra y buena Madre , María Luisa actualmente está estudianto una Licenciatura en la Universidad URACCAN recinto Nueva Guinea, su sueño es tener una vivienda digna, estabilidad laboral, salud y que su hijo siga estudiando para que llegue a ser alguien en la vida.

loans.use: Add a room to home

loans.name: Komla

texts.fr: Komla A. est âgé de26ans et célibataire.  Il chôme depuis un certain temps et arrive à joindre difficilement les deux bouts. Pour gagner de l’argent, il prévoit entreprendre la conduite de taxi moto à Adéta, un village situé à 150 km de Lomé la capitale du Togo. Avec ce 1er  crédit de FECECAV, Monsieur A. espère acheter sa propre moto pour commencer son entreprise.  Avec cette chance de Kiva, il peut commencer à gagner quotidiennement  sa vie.
texts.en:
Komla A. is 26 years old and single. He has been unemployed for some time and has difficulty making ends meet. To earn money, he plans to operate a motorcycle taxi in Adéta, a village located 150 kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. With this first-time loan from FECECAV, Mr. A. hopes to buy his own motorcycle so he can start his business. With this opportunity from Kiva, he can begin to earn a daily living.

Translated from French by Sarah Llewellyn, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy his own motorcycle

loans.name: San Isidro Group

texts.es:
El comité está compuesto por 15 señoras trabajadoras que se dedican a la elaboración y venta de chipas, actualmente el grupo ya está en su 9 ciclo del programa comité de mujeres. La chipa es una comida típica de nuestro país que es bastante consumido, una de las ciudades más tradicionales en donde se puede disfrutar de las mejores chipas es en Caacupé.

De las 15 señoras, 13 se dedican a la venta de chipas, una posee una carnicería y la otra, venta de ropas, todas son vecinas del barrio Gral. Díaz de la ciudad de Caaupé.

Con los préstamos que obtuvieron de la Fundación compraron las materias prima necesarias para elaborar chipas, en esta ocasión tuvieron éxito en la adquisición de sus productos debido a que se juntaron todas y compraron en cantidad a precio mayorista por lo que obtuvieron importantes descuentos.

Todas las integrantes reciben un promedio de gs. 973.000 y lo invierten para la producción de sus productos descriptos más arriba.

Todas las integrantes del comité agradecen a la Fundación por el apoyo y por permitirle ser parte del programa comité de mujeres, actualmente el comité tiene como objetivo lograr la mayor cantidad de venta en estos meses próximos al 8 de Diciembre, que es la fecha de la fiesta patronal en Caacupé, y la ciudad recibe a mas de un millón de visitantes, por lo que hay un potencial importante de clientes y la manera de obtener buena venta es manteniendo la calidad y aumentando la producción, manifiesta la señora Mary Colman.
texts.en:
The committee is made up of 15 hard working women that product and sell Chipas (corn and cheese breads). The group is going through its 9th cycle of the program for women. Chipas is a traditional food for our country and it is very popular for consumers. Caaupe is a city that is traditionally known as a place where you can enjoy some of the best Chipas.

Of the 15 women, 13 sell Chipas, one has a butcher shop and the other sells clothing. They are all neighbours in the region of Gral. Diaz in the city of Caaupe.

With the loans that were acquired through the organization "Fundacion" they purchase ingredients to make Chipas. This time they saw great success in acquiring their ingredients because they all got together and they purchased in great quantities at wholesale prices, granting them significant savigns.

All of the members receive on average 973,000 gs. and they use the funds to invest in the production of their products, as described here above.

All of the members of the committee wish to thank the organization "Fundacion" for the support and for allowing them to be part of the women's program. Currently the committee has an objective to achieve greater sales in these months up to December 8, which is the Patron celebration of Caaupe. During this time the city receives more than 1 million visitors, which translates in a significatn potential for clients. The way to secure a good sales period is to maintain quality in their product but at the same time increase their production. Mary Colman was the speaker.

Todas las integrantes del comité agradecen a la Fundación por el apoyo y por permitirle ser parte del programa comité de mujeres, actualmente el comité tiene como objetivo lograr la mayor cantidad de venta en estos meses próximos al 8 de Diciembre, que es la fecha de la fiesta patronal en Caacupé, y la ciudad recibe a mas de un millón de visitantes, por lo que hay un potencial importante de clientes y la manera de obtener buena venta es manteniendo la calidad y aumentando la producción, manifiesta la señora Mary Colman.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase ingredients to produce Chipas, such as: starch, cheese, vegetable oil. Other women purchased clothing for ladies, men, and children etc.

loans.name: Miumwa

texts.en:
Miumwa is 38 years old, married, and has two children. Miumwa has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for 5 years. She is able to earn approximately $175 each month.  

She is now seeking her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more ingredients and increase her sales and profit.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients to cook and sell food.

loans.name: Sangina

texts.ru: Бобокалонова Сангина проживает   в районе Хуросон. Домохозяйка . Замужем , имеет пятерых детей. Имеет хозяйство , где разводит домашний скот. Занимается продажей молока. Узнав, о возможности получить кредит, обратилась к нам  за кредитом. Решила купить молодую молочную корову, молоко которой сможет продавать  на рынке. Это будет приносить ей и ее семье доход .Погасить кредит сможет в течение 18 месяцев.
texts.en:
Sangina B. lives in the Huroson District. She is married, has five children, and is a housewife. She has a plot of land where she raises livestock, and sells milk as a small enterprise. After finding out about the availability of loans she contacted us about obtaining one. She decided to buy a young dairy cow whose milk she can sell at the market. This will provide income for her family. She will repay the loan over 18 months.

Translated from Russian by Anna Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a cow

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda B., age twenty-six, is married with two children who are both in the elementary school. Linda bakes and sells bread. She bakes the bread with materials such as flour, sugar, margarine, yeast, etc. She sells the bread at an intersection in her community where a number of people pass daily. Linda buys the materials from the surrounding towns. She mixes the flour with the necessary ingredients at the flour mill in her locality. 

Linda wants to expand this business by increasing her production rate to meet the increasing demand of her customers and also supply to her retailers. 

Linda belongs to the group called “Tumi Wura” Trust Bank in her community. The group members guarantee for one another as collateral to access the loan and also to repay the loan.

loans.use: To expand bread-baking business

loans.name: Osioda B -3 Group

texts.en:
Margret M. (back row, far right) is a hardworking business woman who is 35 years old. For two years now, she has been selling smoked fish in Kumi and various neighboring markets. Her profit margin lies at approximately 35% of sales. The loan proceeds will enable M. to purchase more sacks of dried tilapia fish.

M. is married and the mother of four school-going children. Her dream is to sell clothes so her children can go through school successfully. The other members of her group have businesses selling snacks, fruits and vegetables, cereals, and clothes.

loans.use: Purchase sacks of dried tilapia fish.

loans.name: Salomen Ambe

texts.en:
Salomen, born May 26, 1951 is happily married to Ambe Valentine and they have been blessed with 7 children, 4 of them below 15 years of age. Salomen came to know about GHAPE in the year 2003 after encountering some challenges in life such as ill health, death of relatives, and poverty. In order to overcome these challenges, Salomen received her first loan in the year she came to know of GHAPE in the amount of 20,000 frs; she received a loan of 60,000 frs in the year 2004, 80,000 frs in the year 2005, and 150,000 frs in the year 2007. The repayment of the various loans was done promptly.

Given her present loan, she plans to rent a plot for cultivation for 100,000 frs; 50,000 frs will be used for the purchase of seeds, and 50,000 frs will be used for the purchase of fertilizer. She will commence repayment on the fourth month from the day of disbursement. This business will help her community by providing food for them, and many of them will buy from her. With the profit from the loan, she plans to give sound education to her children, complete her house, and bring her daughter who has been sick for a long period of time to the hospital. She prefers to receive a loan from GHAPE because of the social training GHAPE offers, and the issue of collateral security is not a problem.

The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instills a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: Renting farmland for cultivation of crops

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet A. is forty-two years old. She is a married woman with one child: a girl. She says her daughter is currently in the junior high school. Janet lives with her husband and daughter in a rented apartment in Berekum in the Brong Ahafo region. Berekum is a busy business centre which is about twenty-five minutes drive from Sunyani, the regional capital.

Janet deals in printed textile fabrics. She says she procures a variety of fancy and wax prints from a textile depot in Accra and sells in Berekum. She also treks to nearby towns to sell. Janet does not own a shop to sell in; therefore, she hawks to sell her products. She has been in business for eight years. Janet wants a loan to increase her working capital so she can procure more fabrics. She desires to sponsor her daughter through school.

loans.use: To buy printed textiles in bulk

loans.name: Fama

texts.fr: Fama B., 49 ans est mariée avec 07 enfants  en charge. Elle est membre du banc villageois de Niaguis Néma depuis 7 ans. Son activité est la vente de bétail. Elle veut acheter des vaches dans les marchés hebdomadaires pour ensuite les revendre. Ses revenus lui permettent de participer à l’entretien de sa famille. Le prêt qu’elle sollicite sera remboursé au bout de six mois en une seule échéance.
texts.en:
Fama B., age 49, is married and has seven children to support. She has been a member of the village lending group Niaguis Néma for seven years. Her business involves selling livestock. She wants to buy cows at the weekly markets and then resell them. Her income enables her to help support her family. The loan she's requesting will be repaid all at once at the end of six months.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy and resell livestock

loans.name: Vilma

texts.es:
Vilma es socia del Banco Comunal Confianza
Vilma es soltera, tiene 26 años y 1 hijo, Vilma se dedica a la elaboración de empanadas, actividad que realiza en el horno de su tía, sus ventas los realiza de manera ambulatoria por diferentes calles. Además Vilma vende cebiche en la casa de su mama.
Vilma necesita un préstamo de 600 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de una carpa.
Vilma sueña con comprar un terreno para la construcción de su casa y tener un local propio.
texts.en:
Vilma is a member of the Confianza Communal Bank. She is 26 years old, single, and has a son. She makes empanadas using her aunt’s oven and walks the streets selling them by way of a living. She also sells ceviche (raw fish marinated in lemon juice) at her mother’s house. Vilma needs a loan of 600 sols to buy a sales tent. She dreams of purchasing a piece of land on which to build a house and having her own store.

Translated from Spanish by Eleanor Stilgoe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a sales tent

loans.name: Mame Awa

texts.fr: Madame Mame Awa B. est une femme Senegalaise qui est enseignante à Hanene, un petit village.  Elle a travaillé comme enseignante depuis trois ans, et maintenant elle sollicite son premier crédit auprès de l’IMCEC et Kiva pour aider son mari à renforcer son activité.  Son mari est boucher, et parce que Madame B. est salariée, elle peut l’aider avec le financement.  Elle a 28 ans et avec son salaire et les revenus de son mari, ils peuvent régler les dépenses  quotidiennes.
texts.en:
Ms. Mame Awa B. is a Senegalese woman who is a teacher in Hanene, a small village. She has been working as a teacher for three years, and now she's requesting her first loan from IMCEC and Kiva to help her husband bolster his business. Her husband is a butcher. And because Ms. B. earns a salary, she can help him with financing. She is 28 years old. With her salary and her husband's revenues, they can pay off day-to-day expenses.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To help her husband bolster his business

loans.name: Leyla

texts.es:
La señora Leyla, pertenece al Banco Comunal “San Martín de Porras”, vive en el A.A.H.H. Maria Parado de Bellido – Psje. Sta. Rosa, Distrito de Juanjui, Departamento de San Martín. Es conviviente, tiene 30 años, 03 hijos, en etapa escolar y que aún dependen de ella.

Se inicio en la venta de pescado fresco hace varios años atrás, llevada por la intención de ayudar a su familia en sus ingresos económicos, contando para esto con un capital de S/.300 que fue muy bien invertido, por lo que hoy en día continúa con el mismo negocio pero ya en mayores cantidades y variedad de  especies.

Con el préstamo de S/. 1000.00, comprará pescado fresco en kilos tanto los que produce la región como los de la costa del país como: bocachico, palometas, toa, gamitada, tilapias, toyo, pejerey para así mantener surtido su negocio y satisfacer el exigente gusto de su clientela. 

Ella nos manifiesta su complacencia por pertenecer muchos años a un grupo de mujeres que le ha ayudado a superar dificultades que en algún momento tuvo que pasar pero que ahora los enfrenta con mucha fortaleza.
texts.en:
Leyla belongs to the San Martín de Porras community bank. She lives at A.A.H.H. Maria Parado de Bellido – Psje. Sta. Rosa, Juanjui district, San Martín department. She is 30, in a common law marriage, and has 3 school aged, dependent children. She started selling fresh fish several years ago. She was driven by the desire to help her family economically. She started with a very well invested 300 PEN. Today she continues with the same business but with larger quantities and varieties of fish. With a loan for 1,000 PEN she will buy kilos of fresh fish. She will buy fish produced in the region and fish from the coast of the country like bocachica, palometas, toa, gamitada, tilapias, toyo, and pejerey. This way she will keep her business stocked and satisfy the discerning tastes of her customers. She is pleased that for many years she has belonged to a group of women who have helped her overcome difficulties that she had. Now she can confront problems with much strength.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy more and different kinds of fish

loans.name: Lawrence

texts.en:
Lawrence S. is twenty-eight years old. He is not married but he has two children, a boy and a girl, who are currently in the primary school. He lives alone in a rented apartment in Goaso in the Brong Ahafo Region of Ghana. Goaso is one of the busy business centres in the region. His children live their mother.

Lawrence is a trader. He sells all types of mobile phones and accessories such as housing, keypads, etc., in a store at the market square. Lawrence buys his goods from Kumasi. He has been in business for three years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk. He hopes to expand his business and increase his profit margin.

loans.use: To buy phones and accessories

loans.name: Clarita

texts.en:
Clarita T. is 29 years old, married to Gilbert who works as a truck driver. They have two children: Genesis, 5 years old, who is in kindergarten; and Gios, 2 years old. They currently live in Barangay Minante 2, Cauayan City, Isabela. They rent a house at PHP500 monthly.
	
Clarita has had a hog-raising business for quite some time. The income from the business helps with their daily needs at home as well as their monthly expenses such as electricity, rent, etc. She is planning to borrow PHP15,000 as additional working capital to purchase hog feed.  In this way she can ensure that the hogs reach her desired weight and height so they can be sold at a high price. Clarita believes that if someone is patient and hard-working, somehow, that someone will also become successful in return.

loans.use: Business Capital

loans.name: La Union En Progreso Group 2

texts.en:
Juana Barroa is the leader of the group La Union en Progreso (or the Union in Progress) from the small village of Morquecho.

Juana started her business of selling empanadas (a pastry turnover filled with savory ingredients and baked or fried) seven years ago and began taking out loans two years ago to expand her business. She has proven herself extremely credit-worthy and is now on her sixth loan. With this loan she will buy more supplies to make more empanadas, which she sells to her friends, to stores and on the street. Her business has grown so much with these loans that she has been able to buy a motorcycle which allows her to distribute her empanadas to even more locations. 

Juana is the single mother of three children, aged 13, 10, and 8. She says it has been very difficult raising all of them by herself but, with the growth of her business from her loans, she has been able to provide them with enough food and can afford to send them to school. She hopes to continue to grow her businesses so that one day she can send her children to college. 

On behalf of Juana and the entire La Union en Progreso group, thank you for providing opportunities to people who need it most!

loans.use: To buy more ingredients for making empanadas

loans.name: Tesalia

texts.es: Tesalia tiene 31 años, vive con su esposo, quien trabaja en la universidad de su localidad, y tienen 4 hijos en edad escolar. Desde hace 2 años ella se dedica a la venta de comida (platos variados, caldo de gallina y bebidas), todos los días, por las mañanas. Para su negocio mandó a construir una ramada (techo de madera y paja) frente a su vivienda y debajo acondiciona mesas y bancas para servir sus platos de comida. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es que muchas personas degusten de su buena sazón y darles una buena atención es lo que más le importa. Ella considera que su negocio es rentable porque se encuentra en una zona muy transitada y sus clientes acuden diariamente a su puesto. Su deseo a futuro es llegar a tener un restaurante, por lo que seguirá trabajando duro para alcanzar esta meta. Con MFP ya tiene 3 préstamos y lo que le gusta de trabajar con su grupo es porque se apoyan entre sí y son muy responsables en sus pagos. El dinero que ahora solicita será lo invertirá íntegramente en su negocio de venta de comida.
texts.en:
Tesalia is 31. She lives with her husband, who works in the regional university, and their four school aged children. For two years she has been selling food (various dishes, chicken soup, and drinks) every morning. She had a ramada (wood and straw roof) built in front of her house for her business. Under the ramada there are tables and benches so she can serve her dishes. What she likes most about her work is that so many people enjoy her flavorful cooking. Giving them good service is the most important thing to her. Her business is profitable because it is in a busy area. Her customers come to her place every day. Her wish for the future is to have a restaurant. She will keep working hard to reach this goal. This is her third loan with MFP. She likes working with her group because they support each other and are very responsible with their payments. The money she is asking for will be used to invest in her food selling business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Capital to invest in her business

loans.name: Boniface

texts.en:
Boniface is a 27-year-old father of two who owns a small glass supply and fitting business in the Pipeline area of Nairobi. Boniface has run this business for the past three years. He has requested his first loan of Ksh. 50,000 in order to purchase a polishing machine, a drilling machine and a blasting machine for his business. Boniface hopes to one day own a big glass company. On a personal level, he would like to one day own his own home and give good quality education to his children. Boniface describes himself as diligent, patient, God fearing and determined.



Faulu Kenya aims to empower Kenyans by providing relevant financial solutions. Faulu is a sustainable and profitable microfinance institution that offers savings and credit services to over 225,000 Kenyans. Faulu recently became the first MFI in Kenya to be licensed as a Deposit Taking Micro-Finance Company, which will enable Faulu to better serve its clients.

loans.use: To purchase a polishing machine, a drilling machine and a blasting machine

loans.name: Lydiya

texts.en:
Lydiya Z. is 55 years old. She has a husband and lives in a small house in Belaya Tserkov town.

Lydiya sells fruits and vegetables at the local market. She has been in this business for 10 years. She chose this particular business because food is always in demand and thus she will always have clients.

Lydiya would like to borrow 10,000 UAH to purchase seasonal vegetables -- tomatoes, cucumbers, eggplants, etc. This is the time when most people buy this produce and make storages for the winter.

She hopes to make additional income and help her daughter with the wedding expenses, since her daughter is getting married this fall.

loans.use: To purchase additional inventories.

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es:
Juan trabaja como costurero como dependiente, por las noches trabaja como independiente para poder incrementar sus ingresos, es su principal fuente de ingreso con lo que cubre su manutención vive en la casa de sus padres ubicado en la zona de Pasankeri de la ciudad de La Paz.
 
El crédito lo destinará para comprar una maquina de coser para poder facilitar el trabajo que tiene cono costurero de chamarras.
 
Es el primer crédito con Impro, la evaluación realizada permite aprobarle el préstamo solicitado por Juan.
texts.en:
Juan works as a tailor as an employee but at night he works for himself to increase his income. His extra earnings are his primary source of funds to cover household expenses. He lives in his parents' house located in the Pasankeri zone in the city of La Paz. He will use the loan to buy a sewing machine to use in his work in sewing jackets. This is his first loan with Impro whose evaluation process has approved the loan requested by Juan.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a sewing machine to sew jackets

loans.name: Paz Y Fe 1 Group

texts.en:
Yrma is the coordinator of her Banco D. Esperanza (Bank of Hope) Paz y Fe (peace and faith.) Her story is representative of both the members of her group and Eseperanza's Dominican and Haitian (many of whome recently emigrated to the DR from Haiti) clients. Her group is based in the Samana peninsula in the east of the Dominican Republic, where running water (none of which is potable) and electricity are unavailable. Here she makes her home with her husband and five children in a simple structure comprised of wooden walls and a tin roof which she owns but does not have title to.

Yrma originally came to Esperanza over six loan cycles ago for the purpose of improving her business and she has proved herself very successful as an associate of Esperanza, repaying on time every time. She will use this new loan to invest in more products such as plantains, name (a potato like root) and booklets to sell in her store. She plans to use the profits to purchase, clothes, school uniforms, notebooks and shoes for her children, a cow for her family and to continue to improve her home. Additionally, in the long term she would like to save money for a vehicle to move her products and to continue to increase her savings. She would like to thank you all for your support.

loans.use: Plantains, Name and booklets

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of livestock

loans.name: Jorge

texts.es:
Jorge, de 24 años, es un joven muy trabajador, vive en una habitación que le cedieron sus padres y está dispuesto a trabajar muy duro con tal de sobre salir en la vida. 

El día de Jorge comienza a las 6 de la mañana, cuando abre su puesto de ropa y se alista para empezar a vender su mercadería, él tiene su puesto en el mercado Tupac Amaru (mercado importante de la ciudad de Juliaca), donde atiende durante todo el día y a las 9 de la noche cierra, sabiendo que al día siguiente le espera otra larga jornada de trabajo.
Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es conversar con sus clientes y convencerlos de que le compren algo, lleva 5 años realizando esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el mismo lugar. 
Para más adelante, espera tener una tienda más grande donde pueda vender ropa más variada.

Este es el primer préstamo de Jorge con MFP y espera pagar todas sus cuotas sin demora, ya que no quiere causarle problemas a las socias de su banco comunal, donde es muy querido. Con los mil soles solicitados comprará más ropa para implementar mejor su puesto de venta.
texts.en:
Jorge, 24, is a very hard-working young man. He lives in the house that his parents left him. He is prepared to work very hard to succeed in life. Jorge’s day starts at six in the morning when he opens his clothing stand and gets ready to start selling his merchandise. He has a stand in the Tupac Amaru Market (a very important market in the city of Juliaca). He tends his stand all day, and he closes at nine at night. He knows that the next day another day’s work awaits him. What he likes most about his business is talking with his customers and convincing them to buy something. He has been doing this for five years. The most difficult part is having to stay all day in the same place. In the future he hopes to have a larger store where he can sell a larger variety of clothing. This is Jorge’s first loan with MFP. He expects to make all of his payments without fail. He does not want to cause problems for the members of his communal bank, where he is much loved. He will use the 1,000 PEN that he has asked for to buy more clothes to better set up his sales location.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase merchandise

loans.name: Soem

texts.en:
Soem S., 53, currently resides with five children in a small home located in Kampong Chhnang Province.

She works as a cleaner in the busy market and her husband works as a construction worker. The couple can generate an income of at least $4 a day to contribute toward their family’s daily living expenses.

Soem hopes to earn extra income by using a Kiva loan for capital to purchase rice in bulk to sell and gain more profit.

loans.use: To purchase rice in bulk to sell.

loans.name: Rup Laxmi

texts.en:
Mrs. Rup Laxmi S. is a tailor in the town of Tikhidewal, Lalitpur. She lives with her husband and two sons. Her husband works in a government office, and her sons are now studying in the higher secondary school. 




She opened her tailoring shop two years ago. Her specialty is making custom-fitted ladies dresses like the Kurta Sulwar, which are very popular with Nepali women. Before starting her own business, Mrs. S. took a 6-month training course in tailoring from a tailor shop near her home.




She plans to use the loan of Rs 15000.00 to buy raw materials for her tailoring work. She wants to use the shop's income to improve her standard of living and for her son's education.

loans.use: To buy raw materials for her work

loans.name: Juana Lidia

texts.es:
La señora Juana es socia del Banco Comunal “Lupakas” desde hace 3 años atrás, del distrito de Pilcuyo, provincia de El Collao, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 49 años de edad, es casada y tiene 1 hijo. Estudió secundaria completa y se dedica a la compra y venta de ganado y sogas.
Juana nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles pudo aumentar su capital y compró sogas.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 3,000.00 nuevos soles con el cual podrá comprar  hilos, lana y nylon.
Su sueño para el futuro es que su hijo sea profesional y pueda continuar con su negocio.
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro y la puntualidad que hay con las socias.
texts.en:
Juana has been a member of the “Lupakas” communal bank in the Pilcuyo district, El Collao province, and department of Puno, for the past 3 years. She is 49 years old, married, and has one son. She completed secondary studies and she buys and sells cattle and ropes.

Juana tells us that with her first loan at Movimiento Manuela Ramos, which was for 300 PEN, she was able to increase her capital and purchase ropes.

She is asking for this loan of 3000 PEN so that she will be able to purchase thread, wool, and nylon. Her dream for the future is for her son to become a professional and to be able to continue with her business. What she likes most about the communal bank are the savings and the punctuality among the members.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of thread, wool, and nylon

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.fr: Sokhna B. est une femme de 47 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 3 enfants dont elle a la charge. Elle est membre du Bnac Villageois de KA FALL depuis 3 ans et demi. Elle a une bonne expérience avec le crédit pour l’avoir contracté à fois de suite. Elle développe une activité de commerce d’arachide et fait de l'embouche bovine. Ses bénéfices lui permettent de d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Sokhna B. is a 47 year-old woman who is married and has three children to support. She has been a member of the KA FALL village bank for three and a half years. She has a good experience with loans having taken out several consecutively. She is building up a business selling peanuts and also has a beef fattening activity. Her profits will allow her to improve the living conditions of her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Strengthen her commercial activity

loans.name: Mrs. Thy Thuch Village Bank Group

texts.en: Mrs. Thy T. is 52 years old. She is the village bank president of a group of 16 people, located in Tnaot Nhi village in Kandal province. Members will use their loans for different purposes. Mrs. Thy T. is a farmer who owns a one-hectare field to cultivate rice. She would like to ask for a loan of 800,000 Riel from AMK to support her farm. Mrs. Thy T. is a widow with four children. One of her children is a laborer with a private company and the other is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To support her farm

loans.name: Phillippe

texts.en:
Phillippe A. runs a hardware and construction supply store in Lomé, Togo. He is married and has three children.

Phillippe has been in this business since 2005, and is now asking for his first loan from WAGES. He will use this loan to purchase floor tiles and other products used for home construction.

Phillippe purchases his stock in Accra, Ghana, and this loan will help him restock his shelves in order to satisfy his customers’ needs.

loans.use: To purchase floor tiles and other products used for home construction

loans.name: Remedios' Group

texts.en:
Remedios L. is from the village of Brgy. Bonfal West, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 51 years old. Remedios is the group leader of an 8-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Remedios is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Remedios owns & operates a tailoring business. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from providing specialty tailoring services to local community members. Remedios has been engaged in her business for over 7 years and earns approximately 5000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2007, Remedios joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Remedios has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional fabrics & materials. Remedios is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread. This will be the sixth loan taken out by Remedios from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional tailoring equipment such as needles & thread

loans.name: Kastalia Carolina

texts.es: La señora C. G., trabaja como conserje, el salario que recibe es un poco bajo, que no le permite realizar la mejora en su casa con sus ingresos, teniendo que recurrir a este préstamo para poder realizarlo y después ir pagando en abonos suaves, tiene dos hijos en edad escolar. El crédito lo necesita para instalar una puerta y una ventana en la entrada de su habitación, para darle mayor seguridad y protección a la familia
texts.en:
Sra. C. G. has two school age children and works as a janitor. Her salary is a bit low, so her income does not allow her to make improvements to her house. She can only do this with the help of a loan and then repay it in installments. The money will be used to install a door and a window at the entrance of her home, thereby providing greater security and protection for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Install a door & a window at the entrance of her house

loans.name: Eguagia

texts.en:
Eguagia is a native of Edo State, Nigeria. He is into the business of tailoring and sales of sarongs. He has been in this business for 12 years. He sews lovely Nigerian and western styles for his customers. He hopes to own a world class tailoring stall in the future. He has been able to care for his family with the proceeds of his business. He is blessed with a child and his wife is a trader. 

Eguagia needs the loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more tailoring materials and sarongs to sell. He says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring accessories and sarongs

loans.name: Munhtsetseg

texts.en:
Munhtsetseg, 37 years old, lives with her child, mother and sibling in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent, in Govi-Altay Province, Mongolia. Munhtsetseg operates a clothing and consumer goods trading business in her town, selling a variety of men's and women's clothes as well as consumer goods at a local market called Shine-Altai. She started her business in 2000, at a rental counter with working capital of 250,000 tugrugs (~ 185 USD); today, however, as a result of a great deal of hard work and determination and help from her sibling, her working capital exceeds 2,500,000 tugrugs (~ 1830 USD). Munhtsetseg purchases the products and with her sibling sells them through two sales channels at the local market.

Munhtsetseg, an experienced trader who has many plans for the future, says, "I would like to expand my business and purchase my own shipping container for my business." She is now requesting a 2,300,000 tugrug (~ 1685 USD) loan to purchase a large amount of inventory including clothing and consumer goods because demand for her products is increasing.

loans.use: To purchase inventory

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine B. is from the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 46 years old. Josephine is married. To make a living, Josephine owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of different products in the local community with the assistance of her husband. Josephine has been engaged in her business for over one year and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Josephine joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Josephine has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Josephine is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Josephine from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve her house. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To  invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower from Lebanon is a 22-year-old single man. He lives with his two parents and three siblings. Only he and one parent work to support the family. He has been working as a construction worker since 2005. He specializes in cement work. He travels to different sites to serve his clients. 

He is requesting a loan of $1000 from the Kiva partner, Ameen s.a.l. He will use the loan to invest in cement and other materials for his work. This will be his first loan from Ameen. He estimates that his profits will increase by about 25% after taking the loan.

Note: Based on the political and social challenges of Lebanon, personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him  (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his picture, not indicating his name and location, etc.). Ameen s.a.l. appreciates Kiva lenders' understanding of these challenges and encourages lenders to continue their support for Lebanon's borrowers.

Ameen has been able to use its interest-free loan from Kiva to offer lower interest loans with faster disbursement for their micro-loan borrowers. Since its inception, Ameen has provided high quality financial services to over 41,000 borrowers and disbursed over 81,000 loans totaling US $115 million. To learn more about Ameen, please visit: http://partners.kiva.org/partners/115

loans.use: to invest in cement and other materials

loans.name: Samson

texts.en:
Samson T. is from the village of Kabayan, Kadingilan Bukidnon. He is 47 years old. Samson is married and has 3 adult children. To make a living, Samson owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop. The main source of income for the business comes from selling both food & daily use products in the local community. Samson has been engaged in his business for over 3 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Samson joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Samson has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional inventory and as working capital. Samson is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This will be the 2nd loan taken out by Samson from HSPFI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the income of the family. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is an accredited partner of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Zahra

texts.en:
Zahra has been selling clothes since 2005. She sells women's and men's clothes. Zahra is a 43-year-old woman who lives in Lebanon with her husband and their two children. Today, for the first time, Zahra has requested a loan of 2000 USD from Al Majmoua, a Kiva partner, in order to purchase the new summer collection for her shop, as well as to repaint her house.

Zahra is always trying to fill and improve her shop with the latest collection in order to attract more clients. Her clients are her friends and neighbors. Zahra is a determined woman who does her best to improve her sales, as well as her home financial situation. She decided to work in order to provide the best to her children, which starts with the best education. She plans for the future to be able to improve her work.

loans.use: To purchase merchandise and to repaint a home

loans.name: Thimothe

texts.fr:
Commercant de 52 ans ,marie pere de 4 enfants dont l'age varie entre 28 et 2 ans.
En 1990 , quand il perd son travail a cause de la crise ,ou il etait caissier dans un grand Super Marche (Presto)de la place, il commence alors avec la vente du petrole lampant, il associe a cela la location des chaises en plastique et apres en 2006 les appels telephoniques et la vente des  cartes recharges. 
Avec le pret il compte renouveller le stock des chaises en plastique,ajouter  encore 1000l de petrole lampant l'achat des  cartes de recharges en grande quantite des differentes societes de telephonie mobiles.

Certes la vente des cartes ne produit pas de grands benefices , mais il procedera cette fois ci a la vente des cartes en gros, et livrer plusieurs litres de petrole lampant chez les detaillants, eviter les ruptures de stocks; et renouveller ses chaises en plastiques. 
Pour l'avenir il pense qu'il n'est pas trop tard pour lui d'etre un grand homme d'affaire, ouvrir une station service c'est son reve le plus fort.
Tres connu dans le quartier , on l'appelle chef de quartier.
texts.en:
This businessman, 52, is married and the father of four children, aged between 28 and 2 years old. In 1990, he lost his job because of the crisis. He had been a cashier at a big local supermarket (Presto). He began at that point to sell kerosene and to rent out plastic chairs, and after 2006, to sell phone time and telephone recharge cards. With this loan he is intending to renew his stock of plastic chairs, add another 1000 liters of kerosene to his stock as well as a large quantity of telephone recharge cards from various mobile phone companies. It is true that selling the cards does not bring in much profit, but he intends to buy them wholesale this time, and to deliver several liters of kerosene at a time to retailers, avoiding finding himself out of stock, and getting new plastic chairs. For the future, he thinks it is not yet too late for him to become a big businessman. His greatest dream is to open up a service station. He is well-known in his neighborhood, where they call him "Chief".

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of telephone charge cards, plastic chairs, and drums of kerosene

loans.name: Masika

texts.en:
Masika is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She has been operating her food stall business for the last year, selling to her neighbors from home. She owns a house with no electricity but with piped water.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shilling loan, she wants to purchase iron sheets and timber for roofing for her rental houses. In addition, she earns her other source of livelihood from her other business of selling second-hand clothes. 

Masika faces the major challenge of competition from other food-stall operators in the community. She hopes to build three more rental houses in the future. Her main aim of working with Yehu is because of its sustainable financial services to rural entrepreneurs. Her greatest monthly expense is food.

loans.use: To purchase iron sheets and timber for roofing her rental houses

loans.name: Olivia

texts.en:
M. Olivia is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kasubi in the Kampala East region of Uganda.  She is single and has no children.  Olivia has a business of selling second-hand clothing, which she has had for one year.         

Olivia is requesting a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda.  The loan will be used to buy more clothes.  Olivia plans to use the loan in order to expand her business by buying more clothes and generate a profit in order to change her lifestyle.  In the future, Olivia hopes to get married and have a good life.

Note to lenders: BRAC Uganda has recently begun posting a new loan product to Kiva which funds young entrepreneurs in BRAC’s Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program.  This Kiva borrower is receiving a new ELA loan. The ELA program first provides disadvantaged adolescents, usually girls who are out of school, with livelihood training and financial literacy skills.  Afterward, ELA participants can receive microfinance loans to expand their small businesses.  These loans offer adolescents a unique chance to access finance at a young age and improve their prospects for the future, and target a segment of the population not typically served by traditional microfinance.  Kiva is privileged to partner with BRAC Uganda in posting these new loans, and give Kiva lenders the opportunity to fund deserving young entrepreneurs and support a promising new sector in microfinance.

loans.use: To buy more clothes to sell

loans.name: Severiano

texts.es:
El señor Severiano V. tiene 59 años de edad, está casado desde hace tiempo con la señora Severiano Villalba, y viven en su propia casa que está situada en el Barrio San Francisco distrito de Cambyreta.
El señor Severiano y la señora Severiana son propietarios de una Heladería en el centro mismo de la ciudad de Encarnación.
Ellos se dedican a este rubro desde hace mas de 20 años, ya que fue una de las primeras heladerías y es una de las más conocidas de la ciudad.
Gracias a esta actividad ellos han podido criar a sus hijos y darles una buena educación, ya que hoy en día ellos ya son adultos e independientes.
