He has trouble buying bags of coal, so he is asking for a loan of $400 to increase his business and meet the needs of his family. He intends to repay this loan in 12 months without problems. This amount will allow him to restart some other income-generating activities.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer.

Né le 27 Avril 1967 à Lomé, Mr K. Frédéric est un revendeur de charbon à Gbadago. Célibataire, il a un (01) enfant à sa charge. Issu d’une famille misérable, il n’a pas pu fréquenter à cause de manque de moyen ; ce qui a fait que très tôt il a commencé le petit commerce de charbon ça fait 10 ans environ. Il a de la peine à acheter des sacs de charbon donc il sollicite un crédit de 400$ pour relever son commerce et subvenir aux besoins de la famille. Il compte rembourser ce crédit en 12 mois sans problème. Cette somme lui permettra de redemarrer d’autres activités génératrices de revenus.

loans.use: To stock coal

loans.name: Cristo Viene (Christ Is Coming) – Group #3

texts.en:
Maria, pictured second from right, is 65 years old and only has an elementary school education. She has two children and 11 grandchildren. Maria’s husband, Ramon, used to work as a butcher, but had to undergo several operations in the hospital and now is no longer able to work. Because of this, Maria is the sole supporter of her family.

Maria runs a small business selling clothing from her house. Because there are no big clothing stores in Sanchez, Maria goes to the nearby larger cities, such as Santiago and San Francisco, to buy her wares. Most of her clients are her friends and neighbors. She is able to make enough of a profit to support herself and her husband.

Maria’s group meets in her house to repay their loans. Other businesses in her loan group include fishing supplies sales and a seamstress. Also pictured: Ana Garcia, their loan officer, who makes the 40 minute trip out to Sanchez to be at their biweekly repayment meetings.

NOTE: This is a group loan. Maria is one of five microentrepreneurs in her Bank of Hope solidarity group, all of whom have gone through Esperanza's business training courses. Each of the five members will receive a share of this $750 loan for their respective businesses and will be accountable to each other for repaying their share of the loan together. This group-lending methodology ensures that members cooperate to help one another repay their loans and invest wisely in their businesses and families.

loans.use: To invest in their businesses

loans.name: Irma

texts.es:
When the family needs are pressing and you need to take care of them when it is a question of supporting those who you love the most; all of this was the reason that impelled Irma to sell cosmetics three years ago after a friend advised her to do so. Her desires of progress and the establishment of a space to sell clothes pushed her to request a loan in order to make her dreams come true in short time. She is grateful of your support and promises to repay the loan in six months.

Translated from Spanish by Ana Gabriela Clark, Kiva Volunteer.

Las necesidades son apremiantes y urge atenderlas si se trata de sostener a los que más quieres, estos acontecimientos impulsaron a Irma a vender cosméticos hace tres años por consejo de una de sus amigas que le aconsejó para que se dedique a este rubro. Sus deseos de progreso y la implementación de un espacio de ventas de prendas de vestir la impulsan a solicitar un préstamo a fin de cristalizar este deseo en corto tiempo. Agradece vuestro apoyo y se compromete a retornar tu ayuda en seis meses.

loans.use: Establishment of a space to sell clothes.

loans.name: Kyaliwajala D1A Group

texts.en:
The group leader of this small group is Joyce K.. She is currently in the restaurant business and is requesting a loan to buy more foods and furniture. Joyce is a 48 year old widow with 8 children ranging from age 5 to 28. The her children go to school. Each week, Joyce makes approximately UGX 60000 in profits and with the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build a house for the children. Joyce has taken a loan from BRAC Uganda before in the amount of UGX 300000 which she invested in her restaurant and the loan was paid back on time.

Joyce is joined in her small group by Robinah N., Justine N., Eunice A., and Harriet N.. Robinah N. is currently operates a clinic and is requesting a loan to purchase more drugs and a microscope. Justine N. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to invest in the brick business. Eunice A. is currently in the business of maize selling and is requesting a loan to buy more maize form the villages and increase her stock. Harriet N. is currently in the business of brick laying and is requesting a loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To expand restaurant business

loans.name: Ibrahim

texts.en: Ibrahim S. is 35 years old and married with 4 children. He sews dresses and men’s gowns mainly in Makeni town.  With the previous loans, he was able to buy a sewing machine and some materials.  Ibrahim also trains school drop outs who are interested in sewing skills.  He is interested in running his business as a training center for tailoring, as well as for production.  He is, therefore, requesting for a loan of $700 to purchase 3 sewing machines and materials.

loans.use: Ibrahim wants to continue to contribute to the youth in his community and needs additional sewing machines and supplies to continue offering his apprenticeship training activities.

loans.name: Maruja

texts.es:
Maruja is from the district of Vilquechico. She has always proved to be a courageous woman who is determined to get ahead. Since her husband’s death, she has looked for work that will help her and her 4 children get ahead. Currently she sells ropes and bags and, with tremendous hard work and persistence, has managed to build a small house in Juliaca, where she and her family have been living for 4 years. A dedicated mother, Maruja sells her goods in the San Jose market in Juliaca and at fairs in her region. Her biggest wish is to see her children become successful professionals. Recognizing the need for resources to achieve this goal, she decided to increase the variety of her merchandise and is turning to you for this loan.

Translated by Todd Anderson, Kiva volunteer

Maruja, es natural del distrito de Vilquechico, y siempre ha demostrado ser una mujer con mucho coraje y empeño para salir adelante, desde que su querido esposo falleció sólo tuvo en mente la búsqueda de alguna actividad para salir adelante junto a sus 4 hijos. Actualmente con su negocio de compra y venta de sogas y bolsas, con mucho empeño y constancia ha logrado construir su pequeña y humilde vivienda en la ciudad de Juliaca, lugar donde radica hace 4 años en compañía de su familia.Ésta empeñosa madre ofrece sus productos en el mercado San José de la ciudad de Juliaca y en las ferias de los distintos distrito de su localidad; el deseo más grande que tiene es ver convertidos en profesionales de éxito a sus hijos.En esta oportunidad viendo la necesidad económica de su familia decidió aumentar la variedad de su mercadería, con ese propósito recurre a vosotros.

loans.use: Injection of capital to offer a greater number of goods

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet D. sells drinks, both alcoholic and soft. She is married and has three children. Her husband’s income is not sufficient to meet the needs of the family, so she wants to increase her income.

She is running out of stock and is asking for $425 as additional capital to buy more goods for sale.

loans.use: To buy more beverages for sale.
